Could be, but i wanted this to be simpler. There is no advantage of using service loader over explicitly provided thing.
in tempto there was a clear advantage -- if we wanted not to use service loader, we would need to refactor a lot of code (maybe including testng code), or pass information over static fields (:scary:)

nodes.bodyText:
So if you are passing things explicitly why do you need reflection then?

Because airline instantiates the command objects.
We could fix airline for this. eg instead of binding command class, we could bind command factory directly.
Tbd later. cc @electrum

nodes.bodyText: TemptoTestRun?
I want to name the class consistently with the command/subcommand it's bound to.
what about volumes?
what volumes? i don't create any volumes (yet)
Presto?

first, it's presto + tests, not presto alone
second, it's named after standard.yml this corresponds to.
third, please do not rename that file
fourth, we can rename/refactor later, once we forget we had those yml files.
verify version is not empty
Good idea

I would divide this environment into two: presto (or even singlenode-presto) and tests. Standard is meaningless name. Also I would extract constants for presto-master and tests. Or you could could create Standard out of Presto and Tests?
I am not saying this is a bad idea, but out of scope for this PR.

Please extract constant for "/docker/presto-product-tests/conf/presto/etc/config.properties" as this is going to be a path for all config properties for all presto environments.
Also I would move common/standard/config.properties to conf/environment/singlenode/config.properties. It seems to be common, but it is like extending multinode envirnoment where multinode presto config properties is specific to multinode and is stored in docker/presto-product-tests/conf/environment/multinode/multinode-master-config.properties

Also I would move common/standard/config.properties to conf/environment/singlenode/config.properties. It seems to be common, but

I can't mount a config file that doens't exist, because I am mounting a config volume RO.
For good or bad. Bad -- i need default config for presto and for every catalog that we use.
Good -- we won't accidentally create zero-length empty files that cause subsequent failures.

Please extract constant for "/docker/presto-product-tests/conf/presto/etc/config.properties" as this is going to be a path for all config properties for all presto environments.

Good idea
Resources?

DockerFiles is more meaningful.
Also com.google.common.io.Resources.
Maybe you could use supplier for dockerFilesHostPath that would memoize unpackDockerFilesFromClasspath
unpackDockerFilesFromClasspath has side effects, so it's better used explicitly.
I would use something time based instead of randomUUID so it is easier to find these files manually (just in case).
You either want to delete them all or none. If you want to delete by time (eg except last day), use find's switch for that
just call close or something static that close would call also
I don't understand how this should look like. Please explain.
Nevermind... it is minor.
just docker? or even without anything. I often modify such files manually (with vim) shorter paths are easier.

right, but

i use /docker as a "common place to mount various things", so not a mount point itself
i want the path to be meaningful as well, do just /docker is not enough
BTW i use /docker/presto-product-tests because we already use this in existing product tests

Is it expensive to open and close DockerClient? Maybe we could have a singleton for that and we would inject dockerClient into DockerUtil or ContainterManager? Instead of passing this variable around.
It's utility function, so it cannot use a singleton, unless this is a static singleton, which i prefer to avoid (use Guice instead)

It's utility function

My idea was to replace utility class with regular component class (with @Inject constructor etc).
log warning?
this is normal situation: you can't remove a container that you're already removing
Anyway debug logging just in case would nice. Swallowed exceptions are hard to track.
I think you could expose something else that is used for CLI handling. Something where you would use getters and have an option for validation or to inject a logic.
I don't understand how this should look like. Please explain.
EnvironmentsModule? Because it is not specific to any environments but exposes all environment related objects. WDYT?
i think it doesn't really matter. i can change if you want me to.
extract list containers method
I don't understand how this should look like. Please explain.
nevermind.... it is minor
extract list networks method
Same
nevermind.... it is minor
It should be more user friendly.  Or did do some kind of validation and we should not hit the case where there is no environment here.
Good idea!
what do you think with enabling this by default? I know it was causing some issues with running benchmarks couple years back, but maybe it is not going to make some tests flaky. WDYT?

nodes.bodyText:
https://www.testcontainers.org/features/configuration/#disabling-ryuk


The site says

Note that Testcontainers will continue doing the cleanup at JVM's shutdown, unless you kill -9 your JVM process.

Fortunately i didn't see it working as documented :)

TESTCONTAINERS_RYUK_DISABLED environment variable to true.

i can't set the env from within the Java process.
even if i could, i would be very concerned that the lib could have checked the env value before i set it.

nodes.bodyText: ptl -> presto? or presto-test? or prestodev?

i write containers names in command line from time to time, eg docker exec -it ptl-presto-master bash, so the shorter the better.
other option i can consider is pf-
ptl is meaningless. Please prestodev instead. prestodev-presto-master looks good.

ptl is meaningless. Please prestodev instead. prestodev-presto-master looks good.

ptl stands for "product test launcher".
this seems unused.
Done

Do you need that?  What is wrong with having dead container? Would it be possible to do launcher up <environment> and then launcher tempto <environemnt> <tempto options>? could we then use such container or could we add a new one to environment? or completely new container that could only use same network?

Do you need that? What is wrong with having dead container?

That start will detect it failed to start and it will fail.

Would it be possible to do launcher up  and then launcher tempto  ?

Yes!
TBD

or completely new container that could only use same network?

that's the idea
just worker-jvm/ or worker/jvm.config?

i don't see benefit of directories with one-two files.
the files are manually mounted, so they can have more meaningful names and live in one home dir.
just worker-config?
i sometimes open a file by its name only. That's why we have eg HivePartitionManager even though a PartitionManager class in .hive package could (in theory) be as unambiguous.

common/hadoop/hive.properties"

why not just hadoop or env/hadoop or environment/hadoop?

common/hadoop/hive.properties"

why not just hadoop or env/hadoop or environment/hadoop?

convention
- common - this is where all common (reusable env pieces) parts live
  \- hadoop - this is where Hadoop's pieces live
     \- hive.properties - (obvious meaning)

i use common rather than env or environment because hadoop is not an environment.
It's a reusable piece (like a lib code, utility class).
Environments are separate and not meant to be reused.
cmt msg is a bit too long
